nodes.text: Individual teacher quality has a large, measurable impact on elementary students' standardized reading and math achievement when teacher fixed effects are identified using panel data

Method: Use panel data linking students and teachers over multiple years and estimate teacher fixed effects while controlling for student fixed effects, classroom variables, school-year effects, and teacher experience

Data: Longitudinal test-score data (1989-90 to 2000-01) from two contiguous New Jersey elementary school districts with student demographics, teacher identifiers, teacher degrees and experience; test scores on nationally standardized NCE reading and math subtests
Result: Large, statistically significant variation across teachers; a one standard deviation increase in teacher quality raises reading by ~0.20 sd and math by ~0.24 sd on national scales

Result: Teaching experience has positive, statistically significant effects on reading (about 0.20 sd difference between beginning teachers and those with ten+ years), with weaker or no consistent gains in math

Model specification and identifying assumptions: linear regression of student test score on student fixed effects, teacher fixed effects, cubic in experience truncated at ten years, classroom controls, and school-year effects; assumes grade-standardized scores and limited post-cutoff experience effects

Evidence: Tests for systematic classroom assignment and segregation show past achievement and year-to-year mixing of classmates are consistent with no systematic tracking, supporting plausibility of teacher assignment being close to random within school-year-grade cells

Claim / Evidence: Estimates of experience effects that omit teacher fixed effects are biased (generally attenuated); controlling for teacher fixed effects is necessary to isolate true experience returns

Claim: Teacher fixed effects are positively correlated across subjects but correlations vary: moderate correlations among math and comprehension measures (.46-.67) and lower correlations with vocabulary (.16-.32), implying some subject-specific teacher skill variation

Result / Evidence: Variance decomposition gives upper bounds of teacher effects explaining about 5.0-6.4% of total test-score variance and lower bounds 1.1-2.8%; when focusing on policy-relevant variance teachers may explain roughly 4-23% depending on bounds and subject

Conclusion / Policy claim: Because measurable teacher effects are sizable and observable credentials poorly predict them, policies should consider performance-based measures of teacher quality (e.g., evaluation or pay-for-performance) rather than relying solely on credentials

Limitation: Analysis is based on two similar New Jersey districts (elementary grades only), so external generalizability is limited and the estimated magnitudes may be conservative relative to broader geographic variation
